thread.title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: RPI damages Hobart's playoff chances
thread.title_full: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: RPI damages Hobart's playoff chances

author: JOSHUA DeSAIN jdesain@fltimes.com
title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: RPI damages Hobart's playoff chances
text:
Spencer Tulis / Finger Lakes Times RPI at Hobart football 
Hobart’s Marcus Jemison (26) leaps to try and block a pass attempt by RPI quarterback Jeff Avery during Saturday’s Liberty League game in Geneva. RPI 21, Hobart 20 
Key Stat 
RPI quarterback Jeff Avery accounted for all of his team’s scores with three touchdown passes. 
Turning Point 
The Statesmen failed on a fourth down and five at their own 38-yard line early in the fourth quarter that set up the eventual game-winning touchdown. 
And We Quote 
“My mindset right now is, break down the film and try to get better, and find a way to beat Union. I just want to find a way for us to practice well and play hard.” — Hobart coach Mike Cragg Posted: Sunday, October 25, 2015 2:00 pm COLLEGE FOOTBALL: RPI damages Hobart's playoff chances By JOSHUA DeSAIN jdesain@fltimes.com   
GENEVA — With no time left on the clock Saturday, the Hobart football team stood two yards away from a crucial Liberty League victory over Rensselaer. 
Literally seconds earlier, Hobart quarterback Shane Sweeney hit Zach Withers in the corner of the end zone as time expired to pull the Statesmen within one at 21-20. 
The Statesmen opted to go for the win, but Sweeney’s pass was intercepted on the two-point conversion try to give the Engineers a big 21-20 win at Boswell Field. 
“On the last play for the touchdown, they had overloaded one side and we went to Zach Withers for the jump ball. He went up and grabbed it at the high point and made a play for us,” Hobart coach Mike Cragg said. 
“I told them during the timeout before the touchdown that we would go for two. We ran an empty with a slip and I thought (RPI) played good defense. The offense moved the ball all the way down there, I thought that they deserved the chance to earn it. If I had to do it over again, I would do it the same. Put the ball in Shane Sweeney’s hands and let him try to win the game for me.” 
The final play brought the curtain down on a wild second half. 
Trailing by seven at halftime, Hobart (4-3, 2-2) dialed up an impressive drive to open the third quarter. 
Sweeney (16-of-34 for 234 yards) converted a fourth down and 14 at the RPI 25-yard line with a 20-yard pass to Jack Pfohl to keep the drive alive. Tynard Barfield ran in from a yard out to cap a 15-play drive that took 9:24 off the clock and tied the game at 14. 
Hobart failed on a fourth down and five to start the fourth quarter. It gave the Engineers (6-2, 4-1) the ball at the Statesmen 38-yard line. Quarterback Jeff Avery (16-of-25, 160 yards) moved RPI down the field, finally tossing a six-yard touchdown pass to Pat Hogan for a 21-14 lead with 10:46 to play. 
Hobart’s next two possessions of the fourth were stopped on downs by the RPI defense; the first drive reached the Engineers’ 27-yard line. 
RPI got the ball back with 59 seconds left, but Tommy D’Antonio gave Hobart one last chance when he forced a fumble that the Statesmen recovered with 34 seconds remaining. 
Sweeney hit Brandon Shed (8 receptions for 128 yards) for a 39-yard reception down to the RPI 21-yard line with 11 seconds left. 
On the game’s last play with a second to go, Sweeney lofted a jump ball for Withers, who snatched the touchdown to precede the dramatic two-point conversion try that went for naught. 
“I don’t think our pass rush or pass coverage was good enough,” Cragg remarked. “I don’t think we ran the ball as well as we could have today. I loved the heart and fight and character the team showed coming back, but I hate losing worse.” 
The Engineers’ high-powered passing attack, ranked second in the Liberty League, scored the first touchdown on Avery’s six-yard pass to Hogan. Avery keyed the drive with a 41-yard completion to Logan Gadder down to the Hobart nine. 
The Statesmen answered right back with a seven-play, 63-yard drive, finished off by an 18-yard touchdown toss from Sweeney to a wide open Joseph Barrocas. 
RPI went back up late in the first half. Avery connected on another key pass to Gadder (19) yards that helped set up a deflected four-yard touchdown pass to Matt Lane with 1:07 left, giving the Engineers a 14-7 halftime lead.
